comments:
When starting my application (RCP) and opening a JMX connection to a remote
server, the application uses itself commons-logging-1.0.4 for
logging purposes. This library sits in a plugin that exports it. Other
plugins import it as needed.

After I have opened the JMX connection the app is no longer able to display the
help window.

If a restart the application the help does appear, but I can't build a JMX
connection. An NoInitialContextException is thrown that might be caused by the
problematic commons-logging libraries.

The following log entry is written when I try to open the help window after I
opened a JMX connection:

Tomcat plug-in contains commons-logging.jar and used to export it until about 
a week ago.
Could you try if the problem still exist with the latest build?
Thanks.

I've tried the same with the new M6 milestone, however the problem occurs in the
same way as before.

I don't know whether multiple copies of commons-logging.jar can run in various 
plug-ins.  I would think yes, as runtime isolates them from one another.  We 
have seen problems with jars added to the JRE causing problem in Eclipse.  
Could you check you JRE (or better run Eclipse with a freshly installed JRE - 
pass path to Java using -vm command line option), if it does not have Apache 
jars added to ext directory, or somewhere where they would appear on the 
Eclipse boot path?

I start Eclipse with the latest jdk1.5.0_2 with no extra libs in the ext dir except:
dnsns.jar, localedata.jar, sunjce_provider.jar, sunpkcs11.jar.

I have no additional boot path for eclipse.

The stack shows that Logs are loaded using reflection, and the class name must 
somehow be shared between two copies of the commons.logging.
Since plug-ins load classes from their own jars before looking at imported 
plug-ins, the class collision is possible when two implementation exist.

Can you import commons-logging from tomcat plug-in, and not have another copy 
of the jar in the same VM?

I tried importing the commons-logging from tomcat plugin which in turn throws up
a lot more problems than it solves because tomcat give me a whole bunch of jars
that mess up my configuration.

I've also tried to use the exact same version number of commons-logging but that
still does not help. It seems whenever tomcat was loaded it loaded some
libraries that mess up existing ones...

To import packages logging from Tomcat, do not specify tomcat as required 
bundle, only list the packages your plug-in needs.  They will be imported from 
tomcat (because it is the only one that will have them), and will not import 
other jars.
For example in manifest.mf of my hello world plug-in I have:

Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui,
 org.eclipse.core.runtime
Eclipse-AutoStart: true
Import-Package: org.apache.commons.logging,
 org.apache.commons.logging.impl

This will probably not have any effect, but today I removed commons-logging-
jar from tomcat plug-in today, as the plug-in also contains commons-loggin-
api.jar and many classes were included in both.

Use the Tomcat 5.5 plugin found at http://www.sourceforge.net/projects/eclipsehelp and post the .log file in ${WORKSPACE_LOC}/.metadata/.plugins/org.apache.tomcat directory.

This may solve the problem

My M6 contains org.eclipse.tomcat_4.1.130.v20060303 version and it still lists all packages as exported, so I don't think the fix made it.

Also see bug 130292 where I requested the exports to be removed for JMX and other reasons.
This problem should go away now that bug 130292 is resolved. Please confirm.

Even though I'm not the original reporter I do want to confirm that RC1 solves the problem.
Thanks.
